contentText:
Suraj Shrestha [https://miro.medium.com/fit/c/96/96/0*C_wSnltLX62qgRQT.]
[https://medium.com/@syuraj?source=post_page-----87ee63b14ee9----------------------]
Static-site-generator tools like Gatsby [https://www.gatsbyjs.org/] are awesome
tools for creating

 * Sites that has mostly static components
 * Sites that don’t have heavy backend and few api calls to external api
   providers

It is perfect for creating a company portfolio website
[https://www.siristechnology.com/] like we did or developer portfolio website
[https://portfolio.smakosh.com/].

However, there will be cases where we need some backend. For example, saving
feedback message when user submits through contact form
[https://siristechnology.com/contact].

And, it is not feasible or economical to create/deploy/host a complete new app
for such a tiny service.

SO, WHAT CAN WE DO?
Gatsby is not great at proxying api calls in production environment. This link
[https://www.gatsbyjs.org/docs/api-proxy/] only works in dev environment.

COUPLE OF OPTIONS
 * gatsby exports all html into /public folder. You can simple serve static
   files through your express app.

> app.use(express.static(${__dirname}/public`)) e.g. link
[https://github.com/siristechnology/siris-technology/blob/master/server.js#L12]


 * Another easy solution is to run gatsby serve and node express in the same
   port. You can make express run in background daemon using libraries likepm2 .

> web: pm2 start ecosystem.config.js — env production && gatsby serve -p $PORT -H
0.0.0.0


 * Netlify function [https://functions-playground.netlify.com/] is a great
   example and perfect for this type of scenario (static website with some api
   support through function). Netlify free [https://www.netlify.com/pricing/] 
   tier is also adequate for most of the small scale websites, however, the
   price rises sharply after that.
